sections.title: Welcome to the Dark
sections.content:
Grim Delve is a Tabletop RPG of high adventure and low chances. It is a game about desperate people exploring dangerous places for gold, glory, and survival.

In many RPGs, you play as superheroes destined to save the world. In Grim Delve, you are an adventurer. You have grit, steel, and perhaps a spark of magic, but the world does not care if you live or die. If you want to survive, you must be smart, you must be quick, and you must be lucky.

What You Need to Play

  • The Players: 2-5 people to take on the roles of adventurers.
  • The Game Master (GM): One person to portray the world, the monsters, and the challenges.
  • Dice: A standard set of polyhedral dice (d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, d20).
  • This App: To track characters and reference rules.

sections.title: Design Philosophy
sections.content:
This game is built on the Old School Renaissance (OSR) style of play, mixed with modern mechanics. Understanding these pillars is key to enjoying the game.

1. Player Skill over Character Skill

The rules do not solve problems; you do. Do not look at your character sheet to find a "Solve Trap" button. Instead, look at the GM and ask, "I use my ten-foot pole to tap the floor tiles." If you describe a sensible action, you might succeed without rolling a die at all.

2. Combat is War, Not Sport

Combat is not balanced to be "fair." It is a fail-state. If you find yourself in a fair fight, your tactics have failed. Use dirty tricks, bottlenecks, traps, and diplomacy. If you can avoid a fight and still get the gold, you have won.

3. Treasure is Power

You do not gain Experience Points (XP) for killing monsters. Violence is a risk that costs resources (HP, Spells). You gain XP by recovering Treasure and bringing it back to civilization. This aligns your motivation: get the gold and get out alive.

4. The World is Dangerous

Magic is volatile. Monsters are terrifying. The darkness is real. There are no safety nets here. If you drop to 0 HP, you are dying. If you make a mistake, you pay for it.

sections.title: Key Mechanics Overview
sections.content:
Grim Delve uses a unique engine designed for speed and tension.

The Player-Facing Roll

The GM never rolls dice. Players roll to attack, and players roll to defend. This keeps the action centered on you. When a dragon breathes fire, the GM describes the horror, and you roll to survive it.

The Danger Pool

Because the GM doesn't roll attacks, they use Danger Points (DP). When players fail rolls or defeat enemies, the tension rises (represented by DP). The GM spends these points to trigger boss abilities, summon reinforcements, or spring traps. The longer you linger, the more dangerous the dungeon becomes.

Slot-Based Inventory

We do not track weight in pounds. We track Slots. You have a limited number of inventory slots (usually 8-12). A sword takes 1 slot. A ration takes 1 slot. A sack of 100 gold coins takes 1 slot. You will constantly have to choose: "Do I carry this extra potion, or do I carry the loot?"

Modular Classes

You are not locked into a single path. Your class is a combination of two Archetypes. Combine Soldier + Arcanist to make a Spellblade. Combine Rogue + Priest to make a Pilgrim. Your identity is yours to forge.

sections.title: The Setting: Dark Pulp
sections.content:
"Dark Pulp" defines the tone of the world. It is a blend of Sword & Sorcery and Eldritch Horror.

  • Ancient Ruins: The world is old. Civilizations have risen and fallen, leaving behind dungeons filled with technology and magic no one understands anymore.
  • Cosmic Horror: There are things in the dark that do not belong to this reality. Tentacled horrors, geometric spirits, and living spells. Madness is a real threat.
  • Scarcity: Magic items are rare and unique. You won't find a "Magic Sword +1" in a shop. You might find "The Blade of the Black Prince," which glows when goblins are near but whispers dark thoughts to the wielder.
  • Light is Life: The dungeon is pitch black. Torches and oil are your most precious resources. If the lights go out, you die.

Grab your gear, light your torch, and step into the dark. Good luck.

sections.title: The Player-Facing Roll
sections.content:
This game is Player-Facing. The Game Master (GM) describes the world, sets the scene, and controls the monsters, but they do not roll dice. The fate of the characters is literally in the players' hands.

When your character attempts an action with a chance of failure‚Äîattacking an orc, resisting a spell, or picking a lock‚Äîyou make a Check.

The Core Check

To determine the outcome of an action, roll a 20-sided die (d20), add your relevant Ability Modifier, and add your Proficiency Die (if applicable). You compare the total to a Difficulty Class (DC) set by the GM or the enemy‚Äôs stats.

d20 + Ability Modifier + Proficiency Die (if any) vs. DC
  • Pass: If your total equals or exceeds the DC, you succeed.
  • Fail: If your total is lower than the DC, you fail.

Proficiency Dice

Proficiency represents your training. Unlike other systems that use a flat bonus (like +2), this system uses a Proficiency Die. This represents the variable nature of skill under pressure.

  • Untrained: None. Default state for most skills.
  • Trained: +1d4. Gained from your Background.
  • Expert: +1d6. Gained from specific Class Talents.

Rules of Proficiency:
1. No Stacking: You never roll both dice. If you become an Expert in a skill you are already Trained in, the d6 replaces the d4.
2. The Roll: You roll the Proficiency Die with your d20 and add the result to the total.

Advantage & Disadvantage

Situational modifiers‚Äîlike high ground, darkness, or being restrained‚Äîare handled through Advantage and Disadvantage.

  • Advantage: Roll 2d20 and use the Highest result.
  • Disadvantage: Roll 2d20 and use the Lowest result.
  • Canceling: If you have sources of both Advantage and Disadvantage, they cancel each other out. You roll a single d20 as normal.

sections.title: Criticals & Whiffs
sections.content:
The d20 itself tells a story. Rolling a 20 or a 1 triggers dramatic shifts in the narrative, bypassing the math of modifiers and DCs.

Critical Pass (Natural 20)

When the d20 shows a 20, you achieve a Critical Pass.

  1. Automatic Success: You succeed regardless of the DC.
  2. The Crit Choice: You immediately choose ONE of the following rewards:
    • Option A (Bonus Effect): You achieve your goal with supreme style or force. Deal Double Damage, trigger a specific Counter-Move, or gain a useful piece of extra information.
    • Option B (Gain Luck): You bank your momentum for later. You immediately gain 1 Luck Point (up to your maximum).

The Whiff (Natural 1)

When the d20 shows a 1, you suffer a Whiff.

  1. Automatic Failure: You fail regardless of your modifiers.
  2. The Opening: The GM gains 1 Danger Point.
  3. The Disaster: You must roll a d10 on the specific Whiff Table matching your action type (see next section).

sections.title: The Danger Point (DP) System
sections.content:
The players have Luck to save them, but the world has Danger to break them. Danger Points (DP) are a currency the Game Master uses to represent rising tension, the closing in of horrors, and the desperate fury of cornered enemies.

Gaining Danger Points

The world pushes back when the adventurers stumble or when they push too hard. The GM gains 1 DP in two specific instances:

  1. The Whiff (Nat 1): Whenever a player rolls a Natural 1 on any Check (Attack, Defense, Skill, or Save), the GM gains 1 DP.
  2. Blood in the Water: Whenever an Enemy is Defeated (reduced to 0 HP), the GM gains 1 DP. This represents the remaining foes becoming desperate or enraged.

The Danger Pool

  • The Cap: The GM can hold a maximum of 5 Danger Points at any time. Any points gained beyond 5 are lost.
  • The Reset: The Danger Pool resets to 0 when the players complete a Long Rest in a safe haven.

Spending Danger Points

CostAbilityEffect
1 DPActivate AbilityAn enemy uses a specific (Danger) ability listed in its stat block. This allows Bosses to use their most terrifying moves.
1 DPEnd ConditionOne enemy immediately ends one negative condition affecting it (e.g., Stunned, Burning). The boss shrugs off the effect through sheer rage.
1 DPEnvironment TwistThe GM creates a sudden, non-magical complication. A torch blows out, a ledge crumbles, or a door slams shut.
2 DPReinforcements!The noise of combat attracts attention. 1d4 Minion-type enemies arrive.
3 DPRuinous LuckThe GM forces a player to re-roll a successful Check. The player must use the new result.

sections.title: Time & Resources
sections.content:
In a Dark Pulp setting, time is not abstract‚Äîit is a resource that is slowly running out.

The Dungeon Turn

Outside of combat, exploration is tracked in Dungeon Turns (approx. 10 minutes).

  • Moving to a new room.
  • Thoroughly searching for traps.
  • Picking a lock.
  • Taking a short rest to bandage wounds.

The Resource Check

Every 6 Dungeon Turns (1 Hour), the GM calls for a Resource Check:

  1. Consumption: All active light sources and sustenance are consumed. Torches burn out. Lanterns use 1 Oil. Characters must eat 1 Ration or risk Exhaustion.
  2. The Risk Roll: The GM rolls a d6. On a roll of 1, a Random Encounter occurs.

sections.title: Conditions
sections.content:
Positive Conditions

Hidden
You are unseen. Enemies cannot target you with attacks. Your first Attack Check from hiding has Advantage. Ends if you attack or cast a spell.
Invisible
You are unseen even without cover. Advantage on all Attack Checks. Enemies have Disadvantage attacking you.

Disadvantage Conditions

Blinded
Disadvantage on all Attack, Defense, and Sight-based checks. Enemies have Advantage attacking you.
Frightened
You cannot willingly move closer to the source of fear. Disadvantage on all Checks while source is visible.
Flanked
If you are adjacent to 2 or more enemies, you have Disadvantage on all Defense Checks.

Action-Denial Conditions

Dazed
You are rattled. On your turn, you can take either an Action OR a Move, but not both. You cannot take Reactions.
Grappled / Restrained
Your Speed is 0. You have Disadvantage on all DEX Checks and Attack Checks.
Stunned
Incapacitated. You cannot take Actions, Moves, or Reactions. You automatically fail all Defense Checks and Saving Throws.
Confused
You must use your Action to make a melee Attack Check against the nearest creature (randomly determined if multiple are equidistant).

Damage-Over-Time (DoT)

These inflict damage at the start of the turn.

Bleeding
Take 1d4 Physical Damage.
Poisoned
Take 1d6 Poison Damage (Ignores Armor).
Burning
Take 1d6 Fire Damage. Damage increases each round (1d6 -> 1d8 -> 1d10...). Action to extinguish.

Special Utility

Charmed
You cannot attack the charmer. The charmer has Advantage on Influence checks against you.
Weakened
Your strength is sapped. All damage rolls you make are halved (rounding down).
Deafened
Fail all hearing-based Checks. Casting Spells requires a Lore Check (DC 11) or the spell fizzles.
Exhausted
You are pushed beyond limits. Your Speed is halved and you cannot use the Dash action. Only removed by Long Rest.

sections.title: Character Creation Overview
sections.content:
Creating a character in Grim Delve is a modular process. You do not pick a single pre-packaged class that dictates your entire future. Instead, you build a unique identity by plugging together three distinct modules.

The 6-Step Process

  1. Determine Ability Scores: Roll to determine your raw physical and mental attributes.
  2. Choose an Ancestry: Select your species (Human, Elf, Goblin, etc.) to gain innate biological traits.
  3. Select a Background: Define your past life to determine your Skill Training and Starting Gear.
  4. Assemble your Class: Choose Two Archetypes (e.g., Soldier + Arcanist) to define your combat abilities and resource pools.
  5. Calculate Derived Stats: Determine your Hit Points, Inventory Slots, and Defense bonuses.
  6. Finishing Touches: Name your character and define their Drive.

sections.title: Determining Ability Scores
sections.content:
Your Ability Scores define your raw potential. In this system, we do not use the traditional range of 3‚Äì18. We use the Modifiers directly (e.g., +1, +2, -1).

The Six Attributes

  • Strength (STR): Melee attacks, damage, athletics, and inventory slots.
  • Dexterity (DEX): Ranged attacks, dodging, stealth, and fine manipulation.
  • Constitution (CON): Health (HP), resisting poison/fatigue, and stamina.
  • Intelligence (INT): Arcane magic, crafting, history, and investigation.
  • Wisdom (WIS): Divine/Primal magic, perception, survival, and willpower.
  • Charisma (CHA): Occult magic, leadership, deception, and luck.

Generating Stats: The Array

To determine your stats, roll a d12 on the table below. You may assign the numbers from your array to your six Attributes in any order you choose.

sections.title: Ancestries
sections.content:
Your Ancestry defines your biological origin and the innate traits forged by your people's history. It determines your physical capabilities and one unique Ancestry Feat chosen at creation.

The Common & The Exotic

The world is vast and dangerous. While Humans, Dwarves, and Elves are common, you may also play as the small-but-lucky Smallfolk, the junk-tinkering Goblins, or the magically-scarred Draconids.

[[DYNAMIC_ANCESTRIES]]

sections.title: Backgrounds
sections.content:
Your Background describes who you were before you took up the sword or the staff. It represents your past trade, your upbringing, and the skills you relied on to survive civilization before entering the dungeon.

Benefits

Every Background provides three specific benefits:

  1. Skill Training: You become Trained (d4) in a specific Skill or Tool. (If your Ancestry already made you Trained, you become Expert (d6) instead).
  2. Background Feat: A unique, non-combat ability that reflects your experience (e.g., finding safe houses, identifying poisons).
  3. Starting Gear: A specific bundle of equipment to start your journey.
[[DYNAMIC_BACKGROUNDS]]

sections.title: The Modular Class System
sections.content:
In Grim Delve, your class is not a single choice made at Level 1. It is the emergent identity formed by combining two Archetypes. By mixing and matching these building blocks, you define your playstyle, your resources, and your specific Class Name.

The Three Paths

  • Full Class (Same Role): You choose two different Archetypes from the same category (e.g., Soldier + Guardian = Knight). You gain maximum access to that category's Resource and the highest Hit Die for that role. You are a specialist in your field.
  • Hybrid Class (Mixed Roles): You choose Archetypes from different categories (e.g., Soldier + Arcanist = Spellblade). You gain access to two different resource pools (splitting your power), gaining versatility at the cost of raw throughput.
  • Pure Class (Duplicate): You choose the exact same Archetype twice (e.g., Brute + Brute = Berserker). Mechanically, this counts as a Full Class, but allows you to pick 2 Talents from a single list at creation to hyper-specialize.

sections.title: Resource Systems
sections.content:
Your Archetypes determine which Resources you use to fuel your abilities. There are three types: Stamina, Mana, and Luck.

1. Stamina (STA)

Used by Warriors (Soldier, Brute, Guardian, Skirmisher).
Stamina is a tactical pool of physical energy. It recharges in combat via the 'Take a Breather' action or landing a Critical Hit.

  • Full Warrior: Sum of your two highest Physical Modifiers (STR, DEX, CON).
  • Hybrid Warrior: Your single highest Physical Modifier.

2. Mana Points (MP)

Used by Spellcasters (Arcanist, Occultist, Priest, Primalist).
Mana is a large, finite pool of magical energy. It recharges only after a Long Rest.

  • Full Caster: (Level + 1) √ó 2 + Casting Attribute Mod.
  • Hybrid Caster: (Level + 1) + Casting Attribute Mod.

3. Luck & Reagents

Used by Specialists (Rogue, Warden, Leader, Crafter).
Specialists rely on cunning (Luck) and preparation (Reagents).

  • Luck Points: Used to fuel reactive 'Tricks'. Recharges on Long Rest or Critical Hits.
    • Full Specialist: CHA Mod √ó 2 (Min 1).
    • Hybrid Specialist: CHA Mod (Min 1).
  • Reagents: Physical items (bombs, poisons, traps) crafted during Downtime. They consume Inventory Slots and are spent on use.

sections.title: The 12 Archetypes
sections.content:
There are 12 Core Archetypes divided into three roles. Each provides a specific set of Proficiencies and a list of 20 unique Talents.

[[DYNAMIC_ARCHETYPES]]

sections.title: Synergy Feats (The Combo Classes)
sections.content:
While your Archetypes provide your raw tools (Talents), your Class provides your identity. This is represented by Synergy Feats.

Milestone Progression

At Levels 1, 5, and 10, you do not choose a Talent from a list. Instead, you automatically gain a unique feat determined by your specific combination of Archetypes.

  • Level 1: A signature active ability that defines your combat style (e.g., Arcane Strike or Sneak Attack).
  • Level 5: A powerful upgrade to your kit, plus a permanent +1 Attribute Boost to a primary stat.
  • Level 10: An ultimate ability that can alter the battlefield, plus another permanent +1 Attribute Boost.

Class Name Reference

Find your combination below to discover your Class Name.

[[DYNAMIC_CLASSES]]

sections.title: Inventory & Encumbrance
sections.content:
In this system, your inventory is your life. Encumbrance is not tracked by pounds, but by Inventory Slots. This abstraction represents bulk, weight, and accessibility.

Calculating Limits

Total Slots = 8 + STR Mod + CON Mod

Minimum: 8 Slots.

Slot Rules

  • 1 Slot: Standard items (Sword, Shield, Lantern, Spellbook, Ration Pack).
  • 2+ Slots: Heavy/Bulky items (Greatsword, Heavy Armor, 10ft Pole).
  • Bundles (1 Slot): Small items are bundled. 3 Items = 1 Slot (e.g., 3 Torches, 3 Potions, 3 Flasks of Oil).
  • Free items: Worn clothes, one sheathed weapon, and belt pouches do not count.
  • Coins: 100 Coins = 1 Slot. Greed is heavy.

Encumbrance

If you exceed your Total Slots, you are Encumbered.

  • Slowed: Speed is Halved.
  • Struggling: Disadvantage on ALL d20 Checks (Attacks, Defense, Skills).

sections.title: Armor & Shields
sections.content:
Armor provides Damage Reduction, not avoidance. It absorbs the blow so you don't have to.

Armor Rules

  • Armor Score (AS): Subtract this number from physical damage taken.
  • Stacking: Worn Armor (Light/Med/Heavy) does not stack. You use the highest. Shields DO stack with worn armor.
  • Donning: Takes 1 Dungeon Turn (10 mins).
  • Swimming: Impossible in Medium/Heavy armor without magic.
  • Sleeping: Sleeping in Medium/Heavy armor prevents the benefits of a Long Rest.
[[DYNAMIC_ARMOR]]

sections.content:

sections.title: Adventuring Gear
sections.content:
Tools are just as vital as weapons. Managing light and food is the key to surviving the Dungeon Turn.

[[DYNAMIC_GEAR]]

sections.title: The Reagent System
sections.content:
Reagents are the ammunition of the Specialist classes. They are powerful, single-use items crafted from monster parts and raw materials.

1. Raw Materials

Harvested from monsters or found in the wild. 3 Bundles = 1 Slot.

  • Organics: Flesh, venom, glands. (Poisons/Acids)
  • Flora: Plants, fungi, roots. (Healing/Utility)
  • Scrap: Metal, gears, glass. (Explosives/Traps)
  • Essence: Ectoplasm, dust, magic. (Enchanting)

2. Crafting Rules

  • Downtime: Safe crafting. Check vs Craft DC. Success = 1 Batch. Crit = 2 Batches. Fail = Materials lost.
  • Field Crafting: Possible but risky. Takes 1 Dungeon Turn. Disadvantage on the check unless you have specific Class Talents.
[[DYNAMIC_REAGENTS]]

sections.title: The Combat Round
sections.content:
Combat is a chaotic, desperate struggle for survival measured in Rounds. Each round represents roughly 6 seconds of game time.

1. Team Turns

Unlike games where every character rolls for a specific slot, Grim Delve uses Team Turns.

  • The Player Phase: All players take their turns. You may act in any order you choose. You can coordinate actions freely (e.g., "I'll knock him prone so you can stab him").
  • The Enemy Phase: The GM activates all enemies.

2. Initiative

When combat begins, the GM sets an Initiative DC based on the enemy's speed and alertness (usually DC 11 for grunts, DC 15 for assassins).

  • The Roll: One player (usually with the highest DEX) makes a Group Initiative Check.
  • Success: The Players go first.
  • Failure: The Enemies go first.

3. Surprise

  • Ambushing Enemies: If the players successfully ambush the enemy (via Stealth), they automatically pass Initiative.
  • Being Ambushed: If the enemies surprise the players, the enemies go first, and players cannot use Reactions during the first round.

sections.title: Actions & Movement
sections.content:
On your turn, you have a specific economy of action.

1 Standard Action + 1 Move + 1 Free Action

Movement

You can move a distance up to your Speed (usually 30 feet).

  • Breaking Up Movement: You can split your move (e.g., Move 10ft, Attack, Move 20ft).
  • Difficult Terrain: Rubble, mud, or water. Costs 2 feet for every 1 foot moved.
  • Prone: Standing up from Prone costs Half your Speed.
  • Climbing/Swimming: Costs 2 feet for every 1 foot, unless you have a specific Speed for it.

Standard Actions

ActionEffect
AttackMake a Melee or Ranged Attack Check.
Cast SpellCast a spell with a casting time of 'Action'.
DashMove up to your Speed again (Total = 2x Speed). Cannot use in Heavy Armor.
DisengageYour movement this turn does not provoke Opportunity Attacks.
HideMake a Stealth Check to become Hidden (Requires Cover/Obscurity).
Use ItemDrink a potion, throw a lever, or light a torch.

Skill CheckAttempt to pick a lock, kick down a door, or decipher a rune mid-combat.

Reactions

You have One Reaction per round. This refreshes at the start of your turn. Reactions are taken on someone else's turn (e.g., an Opportunity Attack, the Shield spell, or a Guardian's Intercept).

sections.title: Attack & Defense
sections.content:
In this system, Players make all the rolls. The GM never touches the dice.

Attacking (Player vs. Monster)

When you attack an enemy, you roll against their Defense DC.

d20 + Ability Mod + Proficiency Die vs. Defense DC
  • Melee: Uses STR (or DEX if weapon has Finesse tag).
  • Ranged: Uses DEX.
  • Spell: Uses INT/WIS/CHA (depending on Class).

Outcomes:

  • Hit: Total ‚â• Defense DC. Roll Damage.
  • Crit (Nat 20): Hit automatically. Choose: Double Damage OR Gain 1 Luck.
  • Whiff (Nat 1): Miss automatically. GM Gains 1 Danger Point. Roll on the Attack Whiff Table.

Defending (Monster vs. Player)

When an enemy attacks you, they have a static Attack DC. You must roll to avoid being hit.

d20 + Ability Mod + Proficiency Die vs. Attack DC

You must choose one method of defense for the roll:

DefenseStatRequirement / Penalty
DodgeDEXStandard defense. Disadvantage if wearing Medium/Heavy Armor (unless Dwarf/Soldier).
ParrySTR or DEXMust be holding a Melee Weapon.
BlockCONMust be holding a Shield.

Outcomes:

  • Success: Total ‚â• Attack DC. You take No Damage.
  • Crit Success (Nat 20): You avoid the attack and choose: Trigger Counter-Attack (if capable) OR Gain 1 Luck.
  • Failure: Total < Attack DC. You are Hit. Take Damage (minus Armor Score).
  • Whiff (Nat 1): You are Hit. GM Gains 1 Danger Point. Roll on the Defense Whiff Table.

sections.title: Health & Death
sections.content:
Armor Score (AS)

Armor in Grim Delve is Damage Reduction. When you take physical damage (Bludgeoning, Piercing, Slashing), subtract your AS from the total.

  • Example: You take 6 damage while wearing Chainmail (AS 2). You lose 4 HP.
  • Magic: Armor usually does not reduce Magical or Elemental damage unless it has specific enchantments.

Dying (0 HP)

When you reach 0 HP, you fall Unconscious and are Dying.

The Death Struggle

You die permanently if you accumulate 3 Death Failures. Failures reset only after a Rest.

At the start of your turn, make a CON Check (DC 13):

  • Pass: You become Stable (0 HP, Unconscious, not dying). You stop rolling checks until you take damage.
  • Fail: You take 1 Death Failure.
  • Nat 1: You take 2 Death Failures.
  • Nat 20: The adrenaline surges. Reset your Failures to 0, regain 1 HP, and take your turn immediately.

Taking Damage while Dying

While Unconscious, you cannot Defend. Any attack that hits you is an Automatic Critical Hit.

  • The Cost: If you take damage while at 0 HP, you take 2 Death Failures immediately.
  • Massive Damage: If a single hit deals damage equal to or greater than your Max HP, you die instantly.

Stabilizing

An ally can spend an Action to make a Medicine Check (DC 13). On a success, you are Stable (0 HP, Unconscious). You stop rolling checks until you take damage again.

sections.title: Special Actions: Grappling & Stealth
sections.content:
Grappling

To grab an enemy, you use the Attack Action.

  • The Check: Make an Athletics (STR) Check against the target's Reflex Save Value (or their own Athletics/Acrobatics result).
  • Success: The target is Grappled.
    • Speed: 0.
    • Penalty: They have Disadvantage on Attack Checks and Dexterity Saves.
    • Movement: You can move the target at Half Speed.
  • Escaping: The target must use an Action to succeed on an Athletics or Acrobatics Check against your Athletics DC.

Shoving

Make an Athletics (STR) Check against the target's Reflex Save Value. On a success, you push them 5 feet or knock them Prone.

Hiding (Stealth)

You can use the Hide Action during combat if you break Line of Sight.

  • Requirement: You must be Obscured (Darkness, Fog) or behind Cover. You cannot Hide if an enemy can see you clearly.
  • The Check: Roll Stealth (DEX) against the highest Passive Scrutiny among enemies (10 + WIS + Prof).
  • Success: You gain the Hidden condition. You have Advantage on your next attack. Attacking or Casting reveals you.

sections.title: Environmental Hazards
sections.content:
Falling

Creatures take 1d6 Bludgeoning Damage for every 10 feet they fall. Upon landing, they fall Prone.

  • Terminal Velocity: Damage caps at 20d6.
  • Water: Falling into deep water halves the damage.

Suffocation & Drowning

A creature can hold its breath for a number of minutes equal to 1 + CON Modifier (Minimum 30 seconds).

  • The Choke: Once air runs out, the creature survives for a number of Rounds equal to its CON Score.
  • Death: At the end of this timer, the creature drops to 0 HP and is Dying. They cannot be stabilized until they can breathe again.

Extreme Weather

Explorers in Freezing Cold or Scorching Heat without proper gear must make a Fortitude Save (DC 11) every hour. On a failure, they gain 1 level of Exhaustion.

sections.title: Resting & Recovery
sections.content:
The Breather (Short Rest)

A pause in the action to bind wounds and catch your breath. Takes 1 Dungeon Turn (10 Minutes).

  • Cost: 1 Ration (if hungry) or 1 Torch duration.
  • Benefit: You may spend your Hit Die. Roll the die + CON Modifier and regain that many Hit Points.
  • Limit: You have a number of Hit Dice equal to your Level. These recharge on a Long Rest.
  • Stamina: Warriors regain 1d4 Stamina.

The Haven (Long Rest)

A full night's sleep in a safe, fortified location (Town, Inn, or Magical Fortress). Camping in a dungeon does not count unless explicitly stated by the GM.

  • Benefit: Regain ALL Hit Points and Hit Dice.
  • Resources: Regain ALL Mana and Luck.
  • Conditions: Reduces Exhaustion by 1 level.

sections.title: Spellcasting Rules
sections.content:
Magic in Grim Delve is not just a mental attribute; it is a practiced skill. To cast a spell, you must channel energy through a specific discipline.

The Casting Check

Spend the required Mana Points (MP) and roll a Skill Check against the Spell's DC:

d20 + Attribute Mod + Proficiency Die vs. Spell DC

Casting Skills by Archetype

Your ability to cast depends on how you learned to harness power:

ArchetypeSkill UsedLogic
ArcanistLore & Knowledge (INT)Magic is a complex formula. You must recall the exact geometry and pronunciation.
OccultistIntimidation (CHA)Magic is a bargain. You force the entity or the void to obey your will.
PriestScrutiny (WIS)Magic is divine truth. You must perceive the connection between the gods and the world.
PrimalistSurvival (WIS)Magic is nature. You channel the raw instincts of the storm and the beast.

Note: If you are not Trained in the specific skill, you roll only the d20 + Attribute Modifier (No Proficiency Die).

Spell Modification (The Push)

A skilled caster can alter a spell's formula on the fly. You can add any number of Modifications. Each adds +1 MP Cost and increases the Casting DC by +2.

ModificationEffect
EmpowerAdd one additional damage or healing die (e.g., 2d6 → 3d6).
ReachDouble the spell's Range.
WidenAdd 5ft to the Area of Effect (Radius/Cone).
ExtendDouble the spell's Duration.
SubtleCast without verbal/somatic components (Stealth).
SplitSelect one additional target within range (Costs +2 MP).

sections.title: Harvesting Monsters
sections.content:
When a monster dies, it becomes a resource node. Venom, hide, metal, and spirits can be harvested to create Reagents.

The Harvest Action

  • Time: 1 Dungeon Turn (10 Minutes).
  • Limit: 1 Check per corpse. Failure ruins the materials.
  • Capacity: 3 Bundles = 1 Inventory Slot.

sections.title: Crafting Consumables
sections.content:
Crafting turns Raw Materials into Reagents (Bombs, Potions, Kits). This is primarily a Downtime Activity.

The Process

  1. Recipe: You must know the Recipe (via Class Talent or Loot).
  2. Kit: You must have the correct Tool Kit (Alchemist, Poisoner, etc.).
  3. Materials: You must expend the required Bundles.

The Check

Craft & Tinker (INT) vs. Item Craft DC
ResultOutcome
Critical SuccessCreate 2 Batches for the cost of 1.
SuccessCreate 1 Batch (usually 1d4 items). Materials consumed.
FailureCreation fails. Half the materials are wasted.
Whiff (Nat 1)Explosion. All materials lost. Take 1d6 Damage. GM Gains 1 DP.

Field Crafting

Crafting inside a dungeon is dangerous. It takes 1 Dungeon Turn and all Checks are made with Disadvantage unless you have a specific Talent (e.g., Field Alchemy).

sections.title: The Core Loop
sections.content:
Combat is where you survive, but Downtime is where you grow. In Grim Delve, you do not gain XP for killing monsters. You gain XP for interacting with the world.

The Cycle of Play

  1. Adventure: Delve into dangerous places to acquire Treasure (Gold, Gems, Art).
  2. Return: Haul your loot back to a Safe Haven (a town, outpost, or stronghold).
  3. Spend: Invest your wealth into Downtime Activities.
  4. Advance: Successful activities award XP.

The Golden Rule

Treasure is useless until it is spent. Gold sitting in a vault grants 0 XP. To grow stronger, you must waste money on carousing, invest in training, or fund research. The more Gold you spend, the higher your bonus to the Downtime Roll.

sections.title: Leveling Up
sections.content:
Progression is capped at Level 10. When you gain a level, your current XP resets to 0.

XP Threshold

XP Required = Current Level x 10

Example: To go from Level 2 to 3, you need 20 XP.

Leveling Benefits

When you level up, you immediately gain:

  • Hit Points: Roll your Hit Die + CON Mod. (Min 1).
  • Talent: Choose 1 Talent from either of your Archetypes.
  • Milestones (Lvl 5 & 10): Gain a Synergy Feat and a permanent +1 Attribute Boost.

sections.content:

sections.title: Artificing (Enchantment)
sections.content:
Magic items are not bought; they are built. Creating a permanent magic item is a complex Downtime Activity.

The 4 Components

  1. Base Item: A high-quality mundane version (e.g., a sword, cloak, or ring).
  2. Blueprint: A recipe found in a dungeon or learned via Research.
  3. Reagents: 3 Bundles of specific materials (e.g., 3x Fire Essence).
  4. Binding Cost: Gold spent on oils, fluxes, and fuel.

sections.title: Setting Difficulty
sections.content:
As GM, you do not roll dice. You set the bar. Your primary mechanical interaction is setting the Difficulty Class (DC).

Task DCs (Static)

DifficultyDCExample
Easy9Kicking open a stuck door. Intimidating a coward.
Normal11Climbing a rope. Picking a standard lock.
Hard13Disarming a complex trap. Climbing a wet cliff.
Very Hard15Deciphering a dead language. Masterwork locks.
Formidable17+Bending iron bars. Resisting a demigod.

Opposed DCs (Dynamic)

When a player acts against a creature, the DC is defined by the creature's stats:

  • Player Attacks: DC = Monster's Defense DC.
  • Player Defends: DC = Monster's Attack DC.
  • Player Resists: DC = Monster's Save DC.

sections.title: Mastering Danger
sections.content:
The Danger Pool is the engine of tension. Do not hoard points; the cap is 5. Spend them to create a rhythm of pressure and release.

Strategic Spending

  • The Narrative Beat (1 DP): Use Environment Twist to change the battlefield. Collapse a pillar to create cover, or blow out torches to force a lighting decision.
  • The Boss Moment (1 DP): Use Activate Ability to break the action economy. Trigger a boss's special move immediately after a player's turn to disrupt their plans.
  • The Tide Turn (2 DP): Use Reinforcements when the players get comfortable. Adding minions changes the geometry of the fight.
  • The 'No' Button (3 DP): Use Ruinous Luck only for climactic moments. Force a re-roll on a critical success to heighten the drama of the final blow.

sections.title: Traps: The Click Rule
sections.content:
Traps are puzzles, not just HP taxes. They should rarely be a surprise.

The 'Click' Rule

When a player triggers a trap, do not roll damage immediately. Say 'Click'.

  1. The Pause: Describe the trigger (e.g., 'The stone sinks under your boot.').
  2. The Reaction: Ask 'What do you do?'.
  3. The Result:
    • Good Answer: 'I dive flat!' (Grant Advantage on the Save).
    • Bad Answer: 'I step off.' (Trigger normally).
    • Creative Answer: 'I jam my shield in the slot!' (Block trap, shield takes damage).

sections.title: Encounter Design
sections.content:
Combat is a war of attrition. The goal is not to create a fair fight, but to drain resources.

The Budget

Calculate Total Party Level (TPL) (e.g., 4 Lvl 3 PCs = 12).

RoleCostNote
Minion0.25 x Level4 Minions = 1 Standard monster.

Difficulty Scaling

  • Easy (0.5x TPL): Patrols. Burns minor resources.
  • Standard (1.0x TPL): Baseline. Risk of reaching 0 HP.
  • Deadly (2.0x TPL): Major Boss or Blunder. High death risk.

Dynamic Reinforcements

If players are winning too easily, spend 2 Danger Points to spawn 1d4 Minions (Cost ~1 Level) as a second wave.

sections.title: The Overloaded Encounter Die
sections.content:
To track time and risk, roll a d6 every time the party enters a new area, searches a room, or rests.

5Dungeon ShiftA door slams shut, a trap resets, or the environment changes.
6ClearSafe passage. The characters catch their breath.

sections.title: Monster Design Philosophy
sections.content:
In Grim Delve, you do not need to memorize hundreds of stat blocks. Monsters are modular, built by combining two components:

  • The Chassis (Role + Level): Provides the math (HP, Damage, DCs).
  • The Skin (Family): Provides the flavor and special abilities (Traits, Actions).

This allows you to improvise any creature instantly. A 'Level 3 Soldier' can be a Hobgoblin (Folk), a Animated Armor (Construct), or a Skeleton Warrior (Unliving) just by swapping the Family trait.

sections.title: The Roles (Tactics)
sections.content:
Every monster falls into a specific tactical role which dictates its behavior.

‚öîÔ∏è Soldier (The Line)

Balanced defense and offense. They act as the anvil. Tactics: Block choke points, protect Artillery, and engage the strongest PC.

üí™ Brute (The Hammer)

High HP and Damage, but Low Defense. Dangerous to ignore. Tactics: Charge the nearest target and force players to focus fire on them.

üèπ Artillery (The Sniper)

Ranged specialists. Weak in melee. Tactics: Seek high ground or cover. Focus fire on Squishy PCs (Wizards/Rogues).

üó°Ô∏è Skirmisher (The Flanker)

High Defense and Speed, Low HP. Tactics: Hit-and-run. They bypass the frontline to attack the backline, using mobility to avoid counter-attacks.

üß† Controller (The Leader)

Buffers and Debuffers. Tactics: Change the battlefield (Walls, Fog), disable PCs (Stun, Fear), and command Minions.

üíÄ Lurker (The Assassin)

Stealth specialists. Tactics: Hide until the party is engaged, then strike for massive damage. Flee if revealed.

üêú Minion (The Mob)

1 HP. Dies in one hit. Tactics: Swarm to provide flanking bonuses for Elites. They exist to drain resources (Ammo/Spell slots).

üëë Solo (The Boss)

High stats, acts twice per round. Tactics: Spread damage, break locks, and survive. When reduced to 50% HP, the GM gains 2 Danger Points.

sections.title: Reading the Stats
sections.content:
Since the GM does not roll, monster stats are Target Numbers for the players.

  • Attack DC: The number a player must beat with their Defense Check (Dodge/Block/Parry) to avoid taking damage. High Attack DC means the monster is accurate or powerful.
  • Defense DC: The number a player must beat with their Attack Check to hit the monster. High Defense DC means the monster is armored or evasive.
  • Save DC: The number a player must beat with a Saving Throw to resist special effects (Poison, Fear, Magic).
  • Damage: The fixed amount of damage the monster deals on a hit (unless a Critical is rolled against the player).
